column2: It reached down a tiny pink paw and touched a leaf of the brave red rose which every day lies before the skull.
column3: It reached down a tiny pink paw and touched a leaf of the brave red rose which every day lies before the skull.

column2: It plucked the leaf, which made a buckler for its small throbbing breast.
column3: It plucked the leaf, which made a buckler for its small throbbing breast.

column2: It spoke:
column3: It spoke:

column2: The rose and the skull love one another. They understand.
column3: The rose and the skull love one another. They understand.

column2: We do not understand.
column3: We do not understand.

column2: It is peace upon the land.	It is peace upon the land.
He smiles, but he is sad.
column3: He smiles, but he is sad.

column2: He crosses the wide sea, but cares not.
column3: He crosses the wide sea, but cares not.

column2: He goes by saddle, and the mountains hem him in, but now he smiles the more.
column3: He goes by saddle, and the mountains hem him in, but now he smiles the more.

column2: See, the trail is gone!
column3: See, the trail is gone!

column2: Do you see the red rose on his breast?
column3: Do you see the red rose on his breast?

column2: Always the rose is there.
column3: Always the rose is there.

column2: Do you see him look up at the mountains, about him at the trees?
column3: Do you see him look up at the mountains, about him at the trees?

column2: Do you see him lay his head upon the earth?
column3: Do you see him lay his head upon the earth?

column2: Do you still see his smile, the smile which is weary and yet not afraid?
column3: Do you still see his smile, the smile which is weary and yet not afraid?

column2: Look!	Look!
It is the time of war.
column3: It is the time of war.

column2: There is music.
column3: There is music.

column2: The blood stings. The heart leaps.
column3: The blood stings. The heart leaps.

column2: The soul exults.
column3: The soul exults.

column2: Flickering of light on steel, the flash of servant forces used to slay, the reverberant growl of engines made for death, the passing of men in cloth and men in blankets, the tramp of hurrying hoofs, the falling of men who die--can you see this--can you catch the horror, the exultation, the joy of this, I say?
column3: Flickering of light on steel, the flash of servant forces used to slay, the reverberant growl of engines made for death, the passing of men in cloth and men in blankets, the tramp of hurrying hoofs, the falling of men who die-can you see this-can you catch the horror, the exultation, the joy of this, I say?

column2: They come, they go; they run their race, and it is all.
column3: They come, they go; they run their race, and it is all.

column2: Here are those who ride against those who slay.	Here are those who ride against those who slay.
It is he who said in the mountains that riddle of the end and the beginning--who knew that to the heart of nature we must come, for either the end or the beginning of this, our life.
column3: It is he who said in the mountains that riddle of the end and the beginning-who knew that to the heart of nature we must come, for either the end or the beginning of this, our life.

column2: I think he rides to battle with the rose, knowing what fate will come.
column3: I think he rides to battle with the rose, knowing what fate will come.

column2: You know of this biting whistle in the air--this small thing that smites unseen?	You know of this biting whistle in the air-this small thing that smites unseen?
Do you know the mowing of the death scythes? Hark!
column3: Do you know the mowing of the death scythes? Hark!

column2: See! he of the rose is bitten.
column3: See! he of the rose is bitten.

column2: He has fallen.
column3: He has fallen.

column2: He was so brave and strong!
column3: He was so brave and strong!

column2: It is red.
column3: It is red.

column2: The rose upon his breast is red.
column3: The rose upon his breast is red.

column2: His face is white, but still the smile is there; and now it is calmer and more sweet, though still he whispers, 'I know not if it be the end or the beginning!'
column3: His face is white, but still the smile is there; and now it is calmer and more sweet, though still he whispers, 'I know not if it be the end or the beginning!'

column2: He is alone with Nature again.	He is alone with Nature again.
The heavens weep for him.
column3: The heavens weep for him.

column2: The earth pillows him.
column3: The earth pillows him.

column2: He sleeps.
column3: He sleeps.

column2: It is all.
column3: It is all.

column2: It is done.
column3: It is done.

column2: It is the way of life.
column3: It is the way of life.

column2: It is the end and the beginning.
column3: It is the end and the beginning.

column2: He loved the valley, the mountain, the grass, the rose.	He loved the valley, the mountain, the grass, the rose.
Now, since he cherished the rose so well, see, the rose will not leave him.
column3: Now, since he cherished the rose so well, see, the rose will not leave him.

column2: Out of the dust it rises, it grows, it blooms. Against his lips it presses.
column3: Out of the dust it rises, it grows, it blooms. Against his lips it presses.

column2: It is the beginning!
column3: It is the beginning!

column2: He loved, he thought, he knew.
column3: He loved, he thought, he knew.

column2: He is not dead He is with Nature.
column3: He is not dead He is with Nature.

column2: It is but the beginning!
column3: It is but the beginning!

column2: Let the rose press against his lips in an eternal, pure caress. There is no end.	Let the rose press against his lips in an eternal, pure caress. There is no end.
They understand.
column3: They understand.

column2: We do not yet understand."
column3: We do not yet understand."

column2: The pageant of the hills, the panorama of the battle, faded and were gone.
column3: The pageant of the hills, the panorama of the battle, faded and were gone.

column2: The table and the books came back.
column3: The table and the books came back.
